           <td class="blob-line-code"><div class="code-body highlight"><pre><div class='line' id='LC1'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC2'>title       : Dates and Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC3'>subtitle    : </div><div class='line' id='LC4'>author      : Roger D. Peng, Associate Professor of Biostatistics</div><div class='line' id='LC5'>job         : Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health</div><div class='line' id='LC6'>logo        : bloomberg_shield.png</div><div class='line' id='LC7'>framework   : io2012        # {io2012, html5slides, shower, dzslides, ...}</div><div class='line' id='LC8'>highlighter : highlight.js  # {highlight.js, prettify, highlight}</div><div class='line' id='LC9'>hitheme     : tomorrow      # </div><div class='line' id='LC10'>url:</div><div class='line' id='LC11'>&nbsp;&nbsp;lib: ../../libraries</div><div class='line' id='LC12'>&nbsp;&nbsp;assets: ../../assets</div><div class='line' id='LC13'>widgets     : [mathjax]            # {mathjax, quiz, bootstrap}</div><div class='line' id='LC14'>mode        : selfcontained # {standalone, draft}</div><div class='line' id='LC15'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC16'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC17'>## Dates and Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC18'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC19'>R has developed a special representation of dates and times</div><div class='line' id='LC20'>- Dates are represented by the `Date` class</div><div class='line' id='LC21'>- Times are represented by the `POSIXct` or the `POSIXlt` class</div><div class='line' id='LC22'>- Dates are stored internally as the number of days since 1970-01-01</div><div class='line' id='LC23'>- Tmes are stored internally as the number of seconds since 1970-01-01</div><div class='line' id='LC24'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC25'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC26'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC27'>## Dates in R</div><div class='line' id='LC28'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC29'>Dates are represented by the Date class and can be coerced from a character string using the `as.Date()` function.</div><div class='line' id='LC30'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC31'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC32'>x &lt;- as.Date(&quot;1970-01-01&quot;)</div><div class='line' id='LC33'>x</div><div class='line' id='LC34'>## [1] &quot;1970-01-01&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC35'>unclass(x)</div><div class='line' id='LC36'>## [1] 0</div><div class='line' id='LC37'>unclass(as.Date(&quot;1970-01-02&quot;))</div><div class='line' id='LC38'>## [1] 1</div><div class='line' id='LC39'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC40'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC41'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC42'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC43'>## Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC44'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC45'>Times are represented using the `POSIXct` or the `POSIXlt` class</div><div class='line' id='LC46'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC47'>- `POSIXct` is just a very large integer under the hood; it use a useful class when you want to store times in something like a data frame</div><div class='line' id='LC48'>- `POSIXlt` is a list underneath and it stores a bunch of other useful information like the day of the week, day of the year, month, day of the month</div><div class='line' id='LC49'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC50'>There are a number of generic functions that work on dates and times</div><div class='line' id='LC51'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC52'>- `weekdays`: give the day of the week</div><div class='line' id='LC53'>- `months`: give the month name</div><div class='line' id='LC54'>- `quarters`: give the quarter number (âQ1â, âQ2â, âQ3â, or âQ4â)</div><div class='line' id='LC55'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC56'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC57'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC58'>## Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC59'>Times can be coerced from a character string using the `as.POSIXlt` or `as.POSIXct` function.</div><div class='line' id='LC60'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC61'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC62'>x &lt;- Sys.time()</div><div class='line' id='LC63'>x</div><div class='line' id='LC64'>## [1] &quot;2013-01-24 22:04:14 EST&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC65'>p &lt;- as.POSIXlt(x)</div><div class='line' id='LC66'>names(unclass(p))</div><div class='line' id='LC67'>## [1] &quot;sec&quot;   &quot;min&quot;   &quot;hour&quot;  &quot;mday&quot;  &quot;mon&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC68'>## [6] &quot;year&quot;  &quot;wday&quot;  &quot;yday&quot;  &quot;isdst&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC69'>p$sec</div><div class='line' id='LC70'>## [1] 14.34</div><div class='line' id='LC71'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC72'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC73'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC74'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC75'>## Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC76'>You can also use the `POSIXct` format.</div><div class='line' id='LC77'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC78'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC79'>x &lt;- Sys.time()</div><div class='line' id='LC80'>x  ## Already in âPOSIXctâ format</div><div class='line' id='LC81'>## [1] &quot;2013-01-24 22:04:14 EST&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC82'>unclass(x)</div><div class='line' id='LC83'>## [1] 1359083054</div><div class='line' id='LC84'>x$sec</div><div class='line' id='LC85'>## Error: $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors</div><div class='line' id='LC86'>p &lt;- as.POSIXlt(x)</div><div class='line' id='LC87'>p$sec</div><div class='line' id='LC88'>## [1] 14.37</div><div class='line' id='LC89'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC90'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC91'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC92'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC93'>## Times in R</div><div class='line' id='LC94'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC95'>Finally, there is the `strptime` function in case your dates are written in a different format</div><div class='line' id='LC96'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC97'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC98'>datestring &lt;- c(&quot;January 10, 2012 10:40&quot;, &quot;December 9, 2011</div><div class='line' id='LC99'>x &lt;- strptime(datestring, &quot;%B %d, %Y %H:%M&quot;)</div><div class='line' id='LC100'>x</div><div class='line' id='LC101'>## [1] &quot;2012-01-10 10:40:00&quot; &quot;2011-12-09 09:10:00&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC102'>class(x)</div><div class='line' id='LC103'>## [1] &quot;POSIXlt&quot; &quot;POSIXt&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC104'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC105'>I can _never_ remember the formatting strings. Check `?strptime` for details.</div><div class='line' id='LC106'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC107'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC108'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC109'>## Operations on Dates and Times</div><div class='line' id='LC110'>You can use mathematical operations on dates and times. Well, really just + and -. You can do comparisons too (i.e. ==, &lt;=)</div><div class='line' id='LC111'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC112'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC113'>x &lt;- as.Date(&quot;2012-01-01&quot;)</div><div class='line' id='LC114'>y &lt;- strptime(&quot;9 Jan 2011 11:34:21&quot;, &quot;%d %b %Y %H:%M:%S&quot;) </div><div class='line' id='LC115'>x-y</div><div class='line' id='LC116'>## Warning: Incompatible methods (&quot;-.Date&quot;,</div><div class='line' id='LC117'>## &quot;-.POSIXt&quot;) for &quot;-&quot;</div><div class='line' id='LC118'>## Error: non-numeric argument to binary operator</div><div class='line' id='LC119'>x &lt;- as.POSIXlt(x) </div><div class='line' id='LC120'>x-y</div><div class='line' id='LC121'>## Time difference of 356.3 days</div><div class='line' id='LC122'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC123'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC124'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC125'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC126'>## Operations on Dates and Times</div><div class='line' id='LC127'>Even keeps track of leap years, leap seconds, daylight savings, and time zones.</div><div class='line' id='LC128'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC129'>```r</div><div class='line' id='LC130'>x &lt;- as.Date(&quot;2012-03-01&quot;) y &lt;- as.Date(&quot;2012-02-28&quot;) </div><div class='line' id='LC131'>x-y</div><div class='line' id='LC132'>## Time difference of 2 days</div><div class='line' id='LC133'>x &lt;- as.POSIXct(&quot;2012-10-25 01:00:00&quot;)</div><div class='line' id='LC134'>y &lt;- as.POSIXct(&quot;2012-10-25 06:00:00&quot;, tz = &quot;GMT&quot;) </div><div class='line' id='LC135'>y-x</div><div class='line' id='LC136'>## Time difference of 1 hours</div><div class='line' id='LC137'>```</div><div class='line' id='LC138'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC139'>---</div><div class='line' id='LC140'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC141'>## Summary</div><div class='line' id='LC142'><br/></div><div class='line' id='LC143'>- Dates and times have special classes in R that allow for numerical and statistical calculations</div><div class='line' id='LC144'>- Dates use the `Date` class</div><div class='line' id='LC145'>- Times use the `POSIXct` and `POSIXlt` class</div><div class='line' id='LC146'>- Character strings can be coerced to Date/Time classes using the
